SUMMARY



                       RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN

              CULLMAN, ALABAMA WATER TREATMENT PLANT





Description of the Cullman Water Treatment Plant and Regulated Substances in Use



In 1996, the U.S. EPA promulgated titled Part 68 - Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions, after this,

call the "Regulations".  The Regulations in part, require owners of Water Treatment Plants using toxic

substances, to take efforts to prevent and/or reduce accidental releases of those substances, and to

document those efforts in a Risk Management Plan (RMP).  This summary highlights the main points of

the City of Cullman Water Treatment Plant RMP.



The Utilities Board of the City of Cullman, Cullman, Alabama, Water Divisions operates and maintains a

water treatment facility located on Highway 278.  At present, the plant can and does, on occasion,

produce up to 24 million gallons/day (MGD).  The plant currently serves approximately 90,000 people.



Cullman accomplishes disinfection of the water through the addition of chlorine.  Chlorine is the only

regulated substances used at the Cullman WTP.  Cullman stores the chlorine at the WTP in one-ton

containers.



The threshold amount for chlorine is 2,500.  The facility either stores or has in use at times up to 10-14

one-ton cylinders or 20,000 to 28,000 pounds of chlorine on hand.  It was determined that there is no

transportation of chlorine or manufacturing of a regulated substance in the plant operation.  Therefore, the

threshold amount is exceeded.



Plant Changes to Improve Safety



Cullman has successfully operated their chlorine equipment to disinfect water for many years.  As

part of the management program, certain items of construction have been accomplished.



All chlorine cylinders, whether in operation or storage, are contained in an airtight structure.  The airtight

structure is designed so that the loading of new or full cylinders will be passed directly to the

receiving

facility prior to acceptance from the vendor.  The vendor is covered under the Department of

Transportation and not the CAA(r)(7).



The facility, as stated above, will be airtight and shall have at a minimum:  (1) chlorine leak detectors,

(2) automatic valve shut-off system, and (3) air scrubbing unit.



The chlorine leak detectors have been located strategically so as to detect a leak in any part of the facility

with a minimum amount of lapsed time.



A system of automatic valve shut-offs have been installed and will be triggered by a signal from a leak

detector or by a panic button.  Panic buttons are located in the chlorine room itself and at other locations

outside the room.



An air scrubbing unit or air filter has been installed to clean the air of any chlorine as it exhausts from the

facility.  The unit will be designed so as to clean the air in the entire facility based on the cubic feet of air

in the facility.  The unit will be automatically triggered into action when a leak is detected.  When the air is

clean in the facility, an "All Clear" signal will alarm.



The program, as designed, will contain any leak that may occur, warn personnel of the leak, shut off the

cylinder valves, and clean the air through filters so that no chlorine gas may escape outside of the

contained area.



Five Year Accident History



There has been no accidental releases of chlorine in the past five years that have caused onsite or offsite

personal injury or property damage, and offsite environmental damage, evaluation, or in-place sheltering.



Worst Case and Alternative Release Services



To develop a worst-case scenario to the release of toxic substances like chlorine deciding the maximum

amount of substance that could be released is necessary and at what rate of release.  For the Cullman

WTP, the regulations require that the effects of the release of the contents of a full one-ton container

during a ten minute period be evaluated.  This rele

ase volume and rate are used to develop the location of

the toxic end point.



The toxic end point is the maximum airborne concentration below which the EPA believes that nearly all

individuals can be exposed for up to one hour without experiencing or developing irreversible or other

serious health effects or symptoms that could impair an individual's ability to take protective action.  The

Regulations estimate the distance to the toxic endpoint, from the Cullman WTP for chlorine in a forested

area, will be approximately 1.3 miles.



Alternative release scenarios were developed for chlorine.  We assumed that a valve or fuse plugs, either

of which are 1"-diameter and can be below the liquid level in the one-ton cylinder, failed completely.  The

Regulations predict that the release rates for the chemical is approximately 2,500 pounds per minute to

chlorine.  Under the conditions described in the Regulations for the alternative scenarios, the distance to

the toxic endpoint would be approximately 0.7 mile for chlorine.



General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention

Steps



The City of Cullman compiled and maintains safety information related to chlorine and associated process

equipment.  Material Safety Data Sheets (MSDASs) provide important data on the composition and

characteristics of the chemicals.  Cullman maintains extensive operation and maintenance data on all

chemical equipment and piping.  Operators can reference this material to ensure that they maintain all

pressures, temperatures, and flows within safe limits.



Periodically, operating procedures and equipment are reviewed to identify specific hazards and

safeguards.  Opportunities for equipment malfunctions or human errors are identified that lead to

development of safeguards to control and/or prevent those malfunctions and errors.  Finally, all devices

and steps that will detect and/or monitor releases are evaluated.



Standardized procedures develo

ped by the chemical industry are used wherever appropriate.  These

procedures allow employees to work safely and are a source of information to prevent or mitigate the

release of toxic substances.



All employees undergo on-the-job training in the safe handling of chlorine.  Additionally, at a minimum of

approximately once every two years, employees attend training conducted by outside organizations.



Preventive maintenance, inspection, and testing of equipment critical to safe operations have a high

priority for the Cullman WTP.  This program reduces downtime due to equipment failures and lessons the

risks of accidental substance releases.



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies at the Cullman

WTP



The City of Cullman, Alabama strives to prevent accidental releases of toxic chemicals at its WTP.  They

have accomplished this through adherence to recommendations from the chemical manufacturers and

equipment suppliers, periodic training of water treatment employees, and an ongoing preventive

maintenance program on the equipment.



David Freeman, Manager, oversees implementation of the RMP and has overall responsibility for

the development, implementation, and integration of the RMP into Water Treatment Plant operators.  The

City has trained and properly equipped Water Plant staff to respond to small leaks whether in the

chemical containers, container valves and fuse plugs, or system piping.  To date, Cullman's efforts have

been successful.  Only a very few minor releases have occurred, were due to minor system leaks, and

Water Treatment Plant staff repaired those leaks without any injuries or property damage.



Emergency Response Program



If release of chlorine is beyond the capabilities of Water Treatment Plant staff should occur, the Cullman County Emergency Management Agency (EMA) will immediately be contacted.  The Cullman County EMA

serves as a single-point coordination of fire, police, rescue, and all other agenci

es that may be necessary

to respond to both natural and man-made emergencies.  For a significant chemical release at the Cullman

WTP, the City's hazardous material response team, that is part of the fire department, will respond to the

WTP site.  The City has trained this group in all emergency response procedures regarding chlorine and

sulfur dioxide.  Cullman County also has a hazardous material response team that the EMA can contact, if

necessary.
